questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for 1 week. He has also had fatigue, weight gain, and episodic headaches during the past 3 months. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His pulse is 88/min and blood pressure is 155/102 mm Hg. Physical examination shows facial plethora and truncal obesity. The skin appears stretched, with multiple ecchymotic patches over the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are bilateral paravertebral muscle spasms and severe tenderness over the second lumbar vertebra. An x-ray of the lumbar spine shows decreased bone density and a compression fracture of the L2 vertebra. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with Cushing syndrome, relocation of body fat from the body periphery to the body center leads to central obesity and dorsocervical (buffalo hump) and supraclavicular fat deposits (not muscle hypertrophy). Patients with Cushing syndrome typically present with muscle atrophy and weakness due to the catabolic effects of cortisol on protein metabolism.

B) INCORRECT:

About 75% of cases of endogenous Cushing syndrome are caused by pituitary adenomas, which can cause visual field defects by compressing the visual pathways. However, patients with large pituitary adenomas (i.e., macroadenoma) typically present with bitemporal hemianopia (not homonymous hemianopia) due to compression of the optic chiasm. Moreover, most pituitary adenomas that produce ACTH are microadenomas (< 10 mm in diameter) and therefore too small to cause visual field defects.

C) INCORRECT:

Cortisol has both anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. In patients with Cushing syndrome, hypercortisolism promotes apoptosis in monocytes, lymphocytes, and eosinophils, causing an absolute decrease in the number of these types of leukocytes. However, excess cortisol levels also inhibit neutrophil apoptosis and promote neutrophil migration out of the endothelial lining of vessels (demargination), which leads to neutrophilic leukocytosis and a blood leukocyte count that is overall increased.

D) CORRECT:

T-wave flattening on ECG is a sign of hypokalemia, which is a common finding in patients with Cushing syndrome. In these patients, excess cortisol binds to mineralocorticoid receptors, causing increased retention of water and sodium, as well as increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen. These mechanisms lead to hypernatremia and hypertension as well as hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive Chvostek sign is a sign of hypocalcemia. In patients with Cushing syndrome, excess cortisol inhibits calcitriol synthesis. Decreased calcitriol levels cause impaired intestinal calcium absorption and increased renal calcium secretion. However, most patients with Cushing syndrome are normocalcemic because of a compensatory increase in PTH secretion, which stimulates calcium release from the bone.

F) INCORRECT:

Low serum bicarbonate levels are seen in disorders that are associated with metabolic acidosis (e.g., Addison disease). The effect of excess cortisol on mineralocorticoids causes increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen, resulting in alkalosis rather than acidosis. Alkalosis manifests with an elevated, not decreased, serum bicarbonate concentration.
questions.hint: This patient presents with several features of hypercortisolism, including hypertension, facial plethora, truncal obesity, thin, bruised skin, and osteoporosis (indicated by his decreased bone density and pathological vertebral fracture). Because he has no history of glucocorticoid therapy, these features are highly suggestive of endogenous Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of cramping abdominal pain, nausea, weakness, and watery diarrhea for 1 week. He has a history of hypertension for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide. He drinks 6 beers daily and does not smoke cigarettes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. His abdomen is tender to palpation in the mid-epigastrium. His serum sodium concentration is 136 mEq/L, potassium concentration is 2.8 mEq/L, and chloride concentration is 102 mEq/L. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.35. An ECG shows sinus bradycardia with T-wave flattening and U waves. Oral and intravenous potassium supplementation is administered, and the patient is started on intravenous fluid replacement therapy. Eight hours later, his serum potassium concentration is 2.9 mEq/L. A low serum concentration of which of the following is most likely to explain this patient's persistently low serum potassium level?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone increases potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. Therefore, low serum aldosterone would lead to hyperkalemia, not the hypokalemia seen in this patient. In addition, hypoaldosteronism would manifest with metabolic acidosis, which this patient does not have.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has signs of clinically significant hypokalemia that is refractory to therapy. Low serum magnesium interferes with potassium repletion and should be considered in patients with hypokalemia, especially those who are at risk for multiple electrolyte abnormalities due to ongoing gastrointestinal losses (i.e., diarrhea) and a history of heavy alcohol use, as in this patient.

There are at least two mechanisms by which hypomagnesemia may contribute to hypokalemia: first, by disrupting the Na+-K+-ATPases in the basolateral membrane of cells of the proximal convoluted tubule and loop of Henle (because magnesium serves as a cofactor for the enzyme); second, by disinhibiting apical ROMK channels in principal cells, thereby increasing secretion of K+.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin D deficiency is an uncommon cause of proximal renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which can cause hypokalemia. While a patient with RTA might present with weakness, pain, and nausea, laboratory findings would include a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which this patient does not have. Low serum vitamin D would not make the patient's hypokalemia refractory to treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Bicarbonate losses due to a 1-week history of diarrhea could result in low serum bicarbonate, and serum bicarbonate levels can affect potassium shifts into and out of cells. However, a low serum bicarbonate level (metabolic acidosis) is associated with a potassium shift out of cells (H+ ions move into cells in exchange for potassium), which causes an increase, not a decrease, in extracellular potassium. In contrast, metabolic alkalosis can cause hypokalemia because potassium shifts into cells in exchange for H+ ions.

E) INCORRECT:

Insulin shifts potassium into cells, so low serum insulin would cause hyperkalemia, not the hypokalemia seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient is at risk for low serum albumin, a surrogate marker of malnutrition and hepatic synthetic function, due to his history of heavy drinking. Hypoalbuminemia can cause pseudohypocalcemia (due to a decrease in total serum calcium concentration but normal ionized calcium concentrations). However, low serum albumin would not cause hypokalemia that is refractory to repletion.
questions.hint: This patient's history of heavy drinking, which is often accompanied by malnutrition, raises suspicion for a particular laboratory abnormality.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 33 weeks’ gestation, is admitted to the hospital for treatment of preterm labor. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Therapy with nifedipine and betamethasone is begun. The patient continues to have contractions; nifedipine is discontinued and treatment with high-dose terbutaline is initiated. Her contractions resolve. Three hours later, the patient reports fatigue and weakness. Neurologic examination shows proximal muscle weakness of the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Beta-2 receptor agonists, such as terbutaline, can cause hypokalemia by stimulating the Na+/K+-ATPase, which leads to an intracellular K+ shift. Symptoms of hypokalemia include fatigue, proximal muscle weakness, and decreased deep tendon reflexes. The diagnosis is confirmed by a laboratory evaluation of serum potassium levels.

Further adverse effects of beta-2 receptor agonists include tremor, headache, anxiety, tachycardia, and palpitations.

B) INCORRECT:

While anemia can cause fatigue and subjective weakness, it is not associated with proximal muscle weakness and decreased deep tendon reflexes. In addition, the onset of symptoms shortly after exposure to several medications for tocolysis makes another cause more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Serologic antibody testing would be indicated if myasthenia gravis (MG) was suspected to be the cause of a patient's muscle weakness and fatigue. However, in MG, it is usually ocular muscles and mastication muscles that are affected, not the lower extremities, and decreased deep tendon reflexes would not be expected. Furthermore, the rapid onset of symptoms in this patient and a history of recent tocolysis make another cause more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Muscle biopsy is indicated for patients with suspected inflammatory myopathies (e.g., polymyositis, dermatomyositis, or inclusion-body myositis), which would manifest with proximal muscle weakness. However, this most commonly affects the pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles, not the lower extremities. Furthermore, the rapid onset of symptoms in this patient and a history of recent tocolysis make another cause more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

While preterm labor is a potential consequence of chorioamnionitis, it is unlikely to be present in this patient with no fever or pelvic pain. Additionally, a bacterial infection would not explain this patient's fatigue and proximal muscle weakness.

F) INCORRECT:

Thyroid function tests are indicated for patients with suspected thyroid disease. While hypothyroidism can cause fatigue and muscle weakness, other symptoms such as bradycardia, cold intolerance, constipation, and weight gain would be expected. Furthermore, the rapid onset of symptoms in this patient and a history of recent tocolysis make another cause more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Electromyography is indicated in patients with suspected peripheral nervous system, neuromuscular junction, or muscle disease, which all could present with proximal muscle weakness. This patient, however, with no significant past medical history, and recent exposure to several medications for tocolysis, should be evaluated first for medication side effects.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms are an adverse effect of terbutaline, a beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonist.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, muscle weakness, and muscle cramps for the past week. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Three weeks ago, her BMI was 27 kg/m2. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes, dry skin, and decreased deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities. An ECG shows prominent U waves and T wave flattening. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's ECG findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In iodine-sufficient regions, autoimmune thyroiditis (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis) is the most common cause of hypothyroidism, which can manifest with fatigue, muscle weakness and stiffness, hyporeflexia, dry skin, prominent U waves (due to bradycardia) and flattened T waves (due to myxedematous deposits or pericardial effusion in chronic severe hypothyroidism). However, hypothyroidism causes weight gain rather than weight loss. Hyperthyroidism (e.g., in the Hashitoxicosis phase of Hashimoto thyroiditis) would manifest with weight loss but would cause hyperreflexia and moist skin. A different diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune pancreatic beta-cell destruction is responsible for type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), which can cause weight loss and fatigue. Insulin deficiency as a result of T1DM can also result in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which manifests with features of dehydration (e.g., dry skin) and electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., muscle weakness, cramps). However, despite a total K+ deficit, patients with DKA have normal or increased serum K+ levels (since insulin deficiency inhibits K+ entry into cells) and would develop ECG findings of hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia (since the manifestations of an electrolyte abnormality are determined by the electrolyte's serum concentration). Moreover, DKA typically develops in hours, not over a week.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune adrenalitis causes primary adrenal insufficiency, which can manifest with weight loss, fatigue, and features of electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., muscle weakness, cramps). However, adrenal insufficiency would cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia.

D) CORRECT:

Purging behaviors are commonly seen in individuals with eating disorders (e.g., bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa), as well as individuals trying to lose weight rapidly. Signs of dehydration (e.g., dry skin), and rapid weight loss in a young individual should raise suspicion for purging behaviors. Common purging behaviors include self-induced vomiting, laxative misuse, and diuretic misuse. Hypokalemia can occur in patients with purging behaviors as a result of increased renal K+ loss (if the patient is using a loop or thiazide diuretic) or as a result of increased gastrointestinal K+ loss if the patient is repeatedly inducing vomiting or misusing a laxative. Osmotic laxatives such as polyethylene glycol work by drawing water and electrolytes into the gastrointestinal lumen, resulting in rapid fluid (and weight) loss and electrolyte imbalances.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with an eating disorder may use diuretics as a part of their purging behavior but triamterene, a potassium-sparing diuretic, is associated with hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia. Hypokalemia is associated with nonpotassium-sparing diuretics, such as thiazides (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) and loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide).
questions.hint: Fatigue, muscle weakness, and hyporeflexia are nonspecific findings of several electrolyte abnormalities including both hypokalemia and hyperkalemia. However, the ECG findings of prominent U waves and T wave flattening are features of hypokalemia while the ECG findings of hyperkalemia include peaked T waves, flattened P waves, and a widened QRS interval.

questions.text:
Six days after completing a course of chemotherapy for metastatic colon cancer, a 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of persistent vomiting. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 114/62 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased skin turgor and dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is soft; there is no guarding or rebound. Serum studies show:


Urea nitrogen
36 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Glucose
100 mg/dL


Osmolality
313 mOsmol/kg


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.51


PCO2

52 mm Hg


PO2

80 mm Hg


HCO3-
40 mmol/L


Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyponatremia can occur in patients with protracted vomiting if the net sodium loss exceeds the net free water loss, typically due to alterations in renal Na+ handling induced by persistent contraction alkalosis. However, in such a scenario, serum osmolality would be decreased (hypotonic hypovolemic hyponatremia). The increased serum osmolality in this dehydrated patient indicates a free water loss in excess of sodium loss, so hypernatremia would be expected. Hypernatremia occurs following vomiting because gastric secretions have a lower Na+ concentration (approx. 20–100 mEq/L) when compared to plasma.

B) INCORRECT:

In alkalemia there is a decrease in serum H+ concentration, and negatively charged proteins in serum (e.g., albumin) bind to positively charged ions, such as Mg2+, resulting in decreased, not increased, free magnesium levels.

C) INCORRECT:

In alkalemia, there is a decrease in serum H+ concentration, and negatively charged proteins in serum (e.g., albumin) bind to positively charged ions, such as Ca2+, resulting in decreased, not increased, free calcium levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperchloremia typically occurs in the setting of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (e.g., due to severe diarrhea), in which the kidneys retain Cl- to compensate for a low extracellular HCO3- concentration and maintain electrical neutrality. This patient has metabolic alkalosis from vomiting, which is associated with Cl- loss in excess of free water loss (and thus hypochloremia) because gastric secretions have a higher concentration of Cl- (approx. 120–160 mEq/L) when compared to plasma.

E) CORRECT:

The characteristic finding associated with persistent vomiting or excessive nasogastric (NG) suctioning is hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Hypokalemia in contraction alkalosis is caused by several mechanisms. The primary driver is hypovolemia-induced RAAS activation and aldosterone release, which promotes renal K+ and H+ excretion and thereby further contributes to both hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Furthermore, in alkalemia, extracellular K+ is driven into the cell in exchange for intracellular H+ (via Na+/H+ antiporter and Na+/K+-ATPase) to compensate for high blood pH levels. Persistent vomiting or excessive NG suctioning also causes loss of K+ in excess of free water loss; gastric secretions have a higher concentration of K+ (approx. 10–15 mEq/L) when compared to plasma due to K+ leakage via KCNE2/KCNQ1 channels on the lumen of parietal cells.

Treatment of contraction alkalosis (a chloride-responsive metabolic alkalosis) consists of fluid therapy with 0.9% NaCl to correct the extracellular volume loss and replete chloride, thereby ensuring adequate Cl- delivery to the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). Adequate Cl- delivery to the DCT is necessary for the activity of the pendrin exchanger, which reabsorbs Cl- in exchange for excreting HCO3- into the lumen of the DCT. Correction of the volume status usually also corrects any mild electrolyte disturbances, but for moderate to severe electrolyte disturbances, it may be necessary to take further measures (e.g., repletion with potassium chloride for severe hypokalemia). See “Acid-base disturbances associated with GI disorders” table.
questions.hint: This patient presents with persistent vomiting and dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes, increased serum osmolality) following chemotherapy. His blood gas analysis is consistent with metabolic alkalosis (increased pH and HCO3-) with respiratory compensation (increased pCO2). The metabolic alkalosis is the result of volume depletion (contraction alkalosis) and loss of gastric H+.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after the sudden onset of weakness in his legs and upper arms. He explains that he has been under a lot of stress lately preparing for a set of important exams. He had a similar episode 7 months ago the first night after finishing a football tournament with his high school. At the time, the weakness lasted 5 hours and resolved completely without treatment. At follow-up examination 1 week later, the results of a complete blood count, routine serum studies, and an MRI of the brain and spine showed no abnormalities. Medical and family history is otherwise unremarkable. He is not sexually active. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. He smokes 2–3 cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the hip flexors and knee extensors, 3/5 in the shoulder abductors, and 4/5 in all other muscle groups. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ throughout. Sensation is intact. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination of the cranial nerves shows no abnormalities. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is normal. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) can manifest with episodic muscle weakness after stress or exertion, and the proximal limb muscles are usually more affected when the extremities are involved. However, isolated extremity involvement is highly uncommon as an initial manifestation of MG. The small muscles (e.g., extraocular muscles, bulbar muscles) are typically the first to be affected, and involvement of the extremities usually occurs in advanced disease. In addition, the deep tendon reflexes are normal in MG. Moreover, this patient's ECG findings are consistent with a particular electrolyte abnormality, which indicates a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), which typically affects male individuals and has a symptom onset during adolescence, manifests with proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia. However, BMD is characterized by a constant, progressively worsening course, rather than self-resolving episodes. The typical ECG findings of BMD are the result of cardiac fibrosis and dilated cardiomyopathy (e.g., pathological Q waves in the inferior and lateral leads, tall R waves in the precordial leads). BMD can cause a prolonged PR interval (as a result of an atrioventricular block due to cardiac fibrosis) but not prominent U waves.

C) INCORRECT:

Pure motor stroke is typically caused by embolism, and this patient's previous episode of weakness could have been caused by a transient ischemic attack, which is a harbinger for stroke. However, bilateral weakness that predominantly involves the proximal muscle is inconsistent with the occlusion of any specific blood vessel in the CNS. This patient also has no risk factors for pediatric embolic strokes such as septal defects (which cause paradoxical embolism) and valvular atrial fibrillation (e.g., due to rheumatic heart disease). His ECG findings are consistent with a particular electrolyte abnormality, which indicates a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Functional neurological symptom disorder may manifest with episodes of weakness in a patient who has recently experienced psychologic stress. However, the diagnosis can only be established in patients whose symptoms cannot be explained by any recognized medical condition. This patient's ECG findings, which indicate a particular electrolyte abnormality, and his clinical presentation indicate an organic cause for his illness.

E) CORRECT:

Episodes of proximal muscle weakness and hyporeflexia with concomitant ECG findings of hypokalemia are consistent with hypokalemic periodic paralysis (hypoKPP). HypoKPP, the most common cause of periodic paralysis, is typically caused by incompletely penetrant, autosomal dominant mutations of sarcolemmal calcium or sodium channels. These mutations exaggerate the potassium influx that occurs in response to physiological triggers such as sympathetic activation (e.g., during stress or physical exertion) and insulin release (e.g., following a high-carbohydrate meal). Therefore, affected individuals develop episodic hypokalemia and reduced muscle excitability in the context of low serum potassium. The episodes of weakness usually resolve within a couple of hours after onset but can last for several days. The respiratory muscles, bulbar muscles, and extraocular muscles are typically spared during these episodes, and in between episodes, patients typically have normal serum potassium levels.
questions.hint: This ECG shows T-wave flattening in the limb leads, prominent U waves in the precordial leads (with fusion of the T and U waves), ST-segment depression in I, II, and V2 to V6, and a prolonged PR interval.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman with a 5-year-history of anorexia nervosa presents to the emergency department for evaluation of severe leg cramps and generalized weakness during the past 3 days. During the past year, she has had three or four similar episodes of cramps and weakness that occurred when she had hypokalemia. She reports no medication use.
On examination, her blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and her BMI is 17. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
138
136–145



Potassium (mEq/liter)
2.5
3.5–5.0



Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
21

21–30



Chloride (mEq/liter)
110
98–106


Urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
40
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.7
0.6–1.1


Laboratory studies performed 6 months previously showed a potassium level of 3.3 mEq/liter and a creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL.
Which one of the following factors is most likely to explain this patient’s presentation and findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs have been implicated in precipitating hyperkalemia and acute kidney injury but not hypokalemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic malnutrition rarely manifests as hypokalemia unless there are also losses of potassium, but there are some exceptions. In the setting of low oral intake and a high volume of saline without potassium, considerable distal delivery of sodium can lead to urinary potassium wasting. Also, in the setting of refeeding patients with malnutrition, hypokalemia can develop.

C) INCORRECT:

Vomiting leads to excessive loss of hydrogen ions and metabolic alkalosis with renal wasting of potassium.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation — symptomatic hypokalemia without evidence of a metabolic alkalosis — is consistent with lower gastrointestinal-diarrheal potassium loss; surreptitious laxative use is the most likely cause. Although hypokalemia is the predominant electrolyte abnormality seen with laxative misuse, a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis may also occur if there is significant stool loss of bicarbonate. This patient may not have reported her laxative use because she was purposefully trying to hide it or because she may not consider over-the-counter drugs to be medications. Asking her specifically about any laxative use would be helpful at this point.

Key learning point: Patients with recurrent hypokalemia should be asked whether they are taking laxatives.

E) INCORRECT:

Although diuretic misuse may lead to hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis would also be present.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is evaluated for persistent hypokalemia. Three weeks ago, she underwent esophagectomy for esophageal cancer. Before the surgery, her serum potassium level was normal. Since the surgery, she has required daily administration of potassium chloride 40 mEq in 0.5 liter of 0.9% sodium chloride intravenously, in addition to potassium chloride 40 mEq three times daily by means of gastric tube.
Her other current medications are metoprolol succinate, atorvastatin, docusate-senna, and aspirin.
Her blood pressure is 106/55 mm Hg, her heart rate is 106 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. A nasogastric tube had been placed for postoperative vomiting and is on low, intermittent suction. There is also a jejunostomy tube in place for feeding. The surgical incision shows no evidence of infection. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
141
136–145



Potassium (mEq/liter)
2.8
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
82
98–106



Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
40
21–30


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.7
0.6–1.1


Which one of the following conditions is most likely to explain this patient’s refractory hypokalemia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has an elevated bicarbonate level, which most likely represents a metabolic alkalosis from gastric losses of hydrogen chloride as a result of having a nasogastric tube on suction. In this setting, the metabolic alkalosis can cause hypokalemia; as the renal bicarbonate excretion increases, a cation such as sodium or potassium also needs to be excreted concomitantly. Therefore, there are increased renal losses of potassium in this scenario, due to the metabolic alkalosis. Another potential contributor to the hypokalemia in this case is the infusion of sodium chloride; the increase in sodium delivery to the distal nephron also increases renal losses of potassium.

Severe hypokalemia (such as a serum potassium level ≤2.8 mEq/liter) reflects a significant deficit that is challenging to replete with ongoing urinary losses and persistent metabolic alkalosis. One potential strategy is to begin a proton pump inhibitor, which will help limit the metabolic alkalosis. In addition, to treat this hypochloremic or “chloride-responsive” metabolic alkalosis, the patient requires both potassium chloride and infusion of additional saline.

Key learning point: Correcting refractory hypokalemia in a patient with coexisting metabolic alkalosis also requires correction of the metabolic alkalosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Rarely, patients with cancer can have electrolyte imbalance, including hypokalemia, due to ectopic adrenocorticotropin production or other tumor-associated alterations. However, when excess adrenocorticotropic hormone is the cause of hypokalemia, hypertension and symptoms of Cushing syndrome would also be present, and these abnormalities would be present before tumor resection.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 2 pseudohypoaldosteronism, also referred to as Gordon syndrome, is associated with hypertension as well as hyperkalemia, rather than hypokalemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Gitelman syndrome is an inherited disorder linked to inactivating mutations in the SLC12A3 gene, resulting in a loss of function of the encoded thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride cotransporter. The syndrome typically manifests at an earlier age; therefore, a history of electrolyte imbalance predating this patient’s esophageal cancer resection would be expected if Gitelman syndrome were the cause of the metabolic abnormalities.

E) INCORRECT:

Common medications associated with hypokalemia include potassium-wasting diuretics and laxatives, although the latter is not associated with a metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man reports 5 days of weakness and lightheadedness. He has a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, obesity, and heart failure with a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. He takes aspirin, insulin, carvedilol, and furosemide regularly and added metolazone 2 weeks ago after being evaluated for exertional dyspnea and worsening lower-extremity edema. Since then, he has noticed an improvement in his dyspnea and edema. He has not missed any doses of his medications.
Today he has a blood pressure of 105/55 mm Hg, a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 36.8°C. His weight is 116 kg (BMI, 34). Physical examination reveals dry oral mucous membranes, a regular cardiac rhythm with a systolic ejection murmur at the left sternal border, clear lungs, and minimal symmetric bilateral lower-extremity edema. Symmetric proximal muscle weakness (grade 4 out of 5) is noted in the upper and lower extremities. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms and electrocardiographic findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypercalcemia can occur with the use of thiazide diuretics, but this is typically mild and develops slowly; although U waves have been described with hypercalcemia, the ECG would usually show a short QT interval.

B) CORRECT:

Given the recent increase in this patient’s diuretic dose, there is high clinical suspicion for diuretic-induced excess potassium excretion and consequent hypokalemia. This suspicion is further supported by the patient's electrocardiogram (ECG), which demonstrates flattening of the T waves in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF) and prominent U waves in the anterior leads (V2–V6). What initially looks like a prolonged QTc interval on this ECG is actually a “QU interval”; in the leads where the T wave and the U wave can be distinguished (such as in leads V2–6), the QTc appears normal.

Key learning point: The most common electrolyte abnormality caused by loop and thiazide diuretics is hypokalemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal failure could cause some of this patient’s symptoms, but it would not explain the ECG findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Both loop and thiazide diuretics are usually associated with a metabolic alkalosis. A metabolic acidosis can develop if there is poor perfusion of vital organs from severe volume depletion or cardiac dysfunction. Furthermore, metabolic acidosis would not explain the ECG findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypomagnesemia can occur with diuretic therapy but does not cause U waves, and the ECG usually shows clear prolongation of the QT interval.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department (ED) with sharp epigastric pain that radiates to her chest and abdomen. She reports that she has had nausea, dry heaves, and vomiting for the past 2 months and has lost substantial weight as a result. Review of systems is notable for severe weakness.
She has a blood pressure of 92/66 mm Hg, a heart rate of 61 beats per minute, a regular respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 36.4°C.
On examination, she is oriented but drowsy and seems uncomfortable. She has mild abdominal tenderness without rebound tenderness or guarding. Her heart rate is regular with no murmur. Lung sounds are normal, and she has no edema or cyanosis. She has slightly dry mucous membranes, but her skin turgor and capillary refill are normal.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
128
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
1.9
3.5–5.0

Urine dipstick in the ED shows a pH of 5 (reference range, 5–9), a specific gravity of 1.030 (reference range, 1.001–1.035), and trace ketones. A urine pregnancy test, urine drug test, and testing for salicylate, acetaminophen, and ethanol are all negative.
An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate to manage this patient’s hypokalemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral potassium, whether provided through supplements or through potassium-rich foods, such as bananas, is not adequate for this patient, given her profound hypokalemia and electrocardiographic changes. In addition, she is unlikely to tolerate oral intake because of her nausea and vomiting. Once she can tolerate oral intake, potassium-rich foods and oral potassium supplements can be used.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral potassium, whether provided through supplements or through potassium-rich foods, such as bananas, is not adequate for this patient, given her profound hypokalemia and electrocardiographic changes. In addition, she is unlikely to tolerate oral intake because of her nausea and vomiting. Once she can tolerate oral intake, potassium-rich foods and oral potassium supplements can be used. For example, one serving of orange juice contains about 12 mEq of potassium, and bananas are generally thought to provide 1 mEq of potassium per inch of fruit.

C) INCORRECT:

The elevated plasma bicarbonate in this case most likely reflects a metabolic alkalosis from hydrogen chloride losses with recurrent vomiting. Treatment with potassium acetate is not advised, because the acetate will be metabolized to bicarbonate and can exacerbate a metabolic alkalosis. Therefore, potassium chloride is the best formulation of intravenous potassium in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient developed profound hypokalemia in the setting of recurrent vomiting. Gastric fluid has only about 4 mEq of potassium per liter, but patients with recurrent vomiting frequently develop hypokalemia from renal losses; chronic vomiting typically leads to a metabolic alkalosis, and during periods when the patient is not volume depleted, excess bicarbonate is excreted in the urine along with potassium. Secondary hyperaldosteronism (when aldosterone is released in response to angiotensin II rather than in response to hyperkalemia) does not cause hypokalemia. In the past, this has been explained as the effect of distal delivery of sodium on the principal cells, but further understanding of these cells has identified the role of angiotensin II, which inhibits potassium secretion at this site. Thus, the use of potassium-sparing diuretics such as spironolactone is not advised. These agents will not replenish the lost potassium and may contribute to volume depletion in a patient who already has poor oral intake and ongoing gastrointestinal losses.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has severe, symptomatic hypokalemia with electrocardiographic changes (QT prolongation) and requires urgent potassium replacement to avoid further complications, such as arrhythmias and rhabdomyolysis. Because of the severity of the hypokalemia and the abnormal electrocardiogram, the patient should receive intravenous potassium at the maximal rate based on institutional protocol, which usually requires a central line, an intensive care unit-level setting, and cardiac monitoring. The patient may have a significant total-body potassium deficit; potassium stores within cells are substantial, so when hypokalemia develops, deficits are significant. Each 1-mEq decrement in serum potassium may reflect a potassium deficit of up to 100 to 200 mEq.

The elevated plasma bicarbonate in this case most likely reflects a metabolic alkalosis from hydrogen chloride losses with recurrent vomiting. Treatment with potassium acetate is not advised, because the acetate will be metabolized to bicarbonate and can exacerbate a metabolic alkalosis. Therefore, potassium chloride is the best formulation of intravenous potassium in this case.

Key learning point: Severe hypokalemia should be treated with intravenous potassium.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman with no significant medical history or current medication use presents to clinic for evaluation of vomiting, diarrhea, and weakness. She reports 5 days of watery, nonbloody diarrhea and intermittent abdominal cramping. During the first 2 days of her illness, she had roughly eight bowel movements per day and vomited several times. Her oral intake at that time was severely diminished, but she can now tolerate small meals and clear liquids. During the past 36 hours, she has had two semiformed bowel movements, but she still feels weak and shaky. Her 7-year-old son had a similar illness one week ago.
She has a blood pressure of 102/66 mm Hg, a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 36.4°C. Physical examination reveals mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. The abdomen is not distended or tympanitic. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The heart rate is regular with no murmur. Lung sounds are normal, and there is no edema or cyanosis. Mucous membranes are slightly dry. Skin turgor and capillary refill are normal. The rest of the physical examination, including the neurologic examination, is within normal limits.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
138
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.0
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
103
98–106

Leukocyte count (per mm3)

4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)

Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate to address this patient’s hypokalemia?

choices.text: Infuse 1 liter of 5% dextrose solution containing 20 mEq potassium chloride intravenously
Infuse 1 liter of normal saline containing 40 mEq potassium chloride intravenously
Prescribe a short course of oral potassium chloride 20 mEq twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of potassium chloride in glucose-containing intravenous fluids can worsen hypokalemia because glucose infusion prompts insulin secretion, and this action shifts potassium into cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone and amiloride, both potassium-sparing diuretics, can be helpful adjuncts for managing hypokalemia that is related to potassium-wasting diuretics, such as loop diuretics and thiazides. Neither spironolactone nor amiloride is an appropriate treatment for hypokalemia that is caused by gastrointestinal losses.

C) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone and amiloride, both potassium-sparing diuretics, can be helpful adjuncts for managing hypokalemia that is related to potassium-wasting diuretics, such as loop diuretics and thiazides. Neither spironolactone nor amiloride is an appropriate treatment for hypokalemia that is caused by gastrointestinal losses.

D) INCORRECT:

If intravenous fluid is required for volume resuscitation in a patient with mild hypokalemia, it should include potassium, but 40 mEq/liter is excessive if the serum potassium level is only mildly decreased. In addition, when significant amounts of potassium chloride are added to saline, the fluid will be hypertonic (the osmolarity of normal saline is 308 mOsmol/liter; the osmolarity of a liter of saline with 40 mEq of potassium chloride is 388 mOsmol/liter).

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s history is consistent with viral gastroenteritis. Profuse watery diarrhea can result in significant gastrointestinal potassium losses, given that each liter of stool may contain up to 80 to 90 mEq of potassium.

For patients with mild hypokalemia (serum potassium level, 3.0–3.5 mEq/liter) who can tolerate oral fluids and food, oral potassium supplementation over several days is generally recommended. This approach is preferred over intravenous administration, because it allows the potassium to enter circulation more slowly.

For patients who cannot tolerate oral potassium supplementation or who have a serum potassium level less than 3.0 mEq/liter, intravenous potassium replacement can be given, but this requires careful monitoring. The maximum recommended rate of intravenous replacement via a peripheral venous catheter is 20 mEq/hour; faster rates may be considered in symptomatic patients, but this would require a central venous catheter and cardiac monitoring. Intravenous potassium replacement is typically administered in crystalloid solutions containing saline or lactated Ringer solution.

Key learning point: In a patient who has mild hypokalemia caused by diarrhea and who can tolerate food, the optimal management approach is oral potassium replacement.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl with high-risk B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, who has a central line for the induction phase of chemotherapy, is hospitalized with fever and neutropenia. Treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics is initiated, but her fever persists, and empiric amphotericin B is started.
On day 3 of amphotericin treatment, she reports having lower-extremity cramping and weakness when she got out of bed in the morning to use the bathroom. She also reports fatigue and says that her stomach hurts because she has not had a bowel movement in several days.
Results of a metabolic panel are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
135
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
2.1
3.4–4.7


Chloride (mEq/liter)
107
97–107


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
24
22–26


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
10
5–18


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.5–1.0


Magnesium (mEq/liter)
1.5
1.26–2.1


An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following initial interventions should be used to treat this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Maintenance fluids with 5% dextrose in 0.45% normal saline and 40 mEq/liter potassium chloride
1–2 mEq/kg potassium chloride administered by mouth in a single dose, repeated if necessary
Intravenous infusion of fluid containing 40 mEq/liter potassium chloride, administered at a rate not to exceed 1 mEq/kg/hour
Calcium gluconate 1000 mg administered intravenously over 2 to 3 minutes
Maintenance fluids with 5% dextrose in 0.45% normal saline and 20 mEq/liter potassium chloride

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maintenance fluids with 40 mEq/liter potassium chloride would provide additional potassium; however, this intervention is not necessary in a patient who does not require fluids.

B) INCORRECT:

Orally administered potassium chloride is a safe, effective treatment that can be given as a supplement to intravenous potassium therapy or in mild-to-moderate cases of hypokalemia. It should not be used to treat severe hypokalemia except in patients without intravenous access; in these patients, oral potassium chloride would be an acceptable first step in treatment until access is secured.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical symptoms and electrocardiographic findings, in the setting of amphotericin use, raise concerns for severe hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia (defined as a serum potassium level <3.4 mEq/liter) results from diminished potassium intake, increased potassium output (via gastrointestinal or renal losses), or transcellular shifts. It is a known complication of amphotericin treatment, which leads to tubular wasting of potassium from the kidney and can also cause kidney injury. Common symptoms and clinical findings in hypokalemia include arrhythmias and weakness and cramping of skeletal muscles. Such symptoms do not typically occur until the potassium level has declined to <2.5 mEq/liter (severe hypokalemia), but they may also manifest at a potassium level of 2.5 to 3.0 mEq/liter (moderate hypokalemia) if the level is falling quickly.

Electrocardiogram (ECG) findings can support the diagnosis of hypokalemia and determine the effect on the myocardium. Typically, the first ECG findings include decreased T-wave amplitude, followed by ST-interval depression, T-wave inversions, PR-interval prolongation, and development of U waves. The precordial leads of this patient’s ECG show the T-wave inversion followed by a U wave.

Treatment for hypokalemia consists of potassium repletion, and the mode of repletion depends on the patient’s symptoms and degree of hypokalemia. Given this patient’s clinical symptoms and ECG findings, the hypokalemia is likely to be severe, and intravenous potassium should be given. The concentration of potassium chloride administered is typically between 20 and 40 mEq/liter if administered through a peripheral line. If given at a higher concentration, the infusion requires a central line and closer monitoring in an intensive care unit. The rate for intravenous infusion should not exceed 1 mEq/kg of body weight per hour. During intravenous potassium supplementation, patients should receive close cardiac monitoring.

Key learning point: A patient whose clinical symptoms, laboratory results, and electrocardiographic findings are consistent with severe hypokalemia should be treated with intravenous potassium chloride.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous calcium gluconate is used to treat symptomatic hypocalcemia, which typically manifests with muscle twitching, tingling, carpopedal spasms of the hands and feet, perioral numbness, and possibly seizures. An ECG would show a prolonged ST segment and corrected QT interval. Calcium gluconate can also be used to stabilize the myocardium in patients with severe hyperkalemia, but this patient has severe hypokalemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Maintenance fluids with 20 mEq/liter potassium chloride would meet maintenance requirements for this patient but would not treat severe hypokalemia. Furthermore, there is no indication that this patient requires parenteral maintenance fluids as part of her therapy.

questions.text: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the office because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography shows sinus rhythm with prominent U waves in the precordial leads. The addition of which of the following drugs would most likely have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Torsemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the resorption of potassium in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It can also cause hypokalemia and would exacerbate the thiazide-induced hypokalemia seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, like amlodipine, is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia. Moreover, the combination of drugs from the same class is not recommended for the treatment of hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist that acts centrally to decrease peripheral vascular resistance. Clonidine has no effect on potassium excretion and would not have prevented this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.

D) CORRECT:

Eplerenone is an effective adjunct antihypertensive medication in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension. In addition, the drug's potassium-sparing properties are useful in patients who develop hypokalemia due to the use of potassium-wasting diuretics (e.g., loop and thiazide diuretics). Eplerenone inhibits the effect of aldosterone and, therefore, decreases K+ excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 77/min
– Normal cardiac axis
– Prolonged PR interval (~220 ms)
– ST-segment depression in I, II, and V2 to V6 (example indicated by red overlay in V2 zoom box)
– T-wave flattening in the limb leads
– Prominent U waves in the precordial leads, with fusion of the T and U waves (examples indicated by purple and green overlays respectively). The P waves in these leads (example indicated by blue overlay) are also mostly buried in the U waves.

These findings are characteristic of severe hypokalemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine is a direct peripheral vasodilator that is used to decrease peripheral vascular resistance in patients with severe and/or treatment-resistant hypertension. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations of hypokalemia (e.g., muscle cramps, weakness, and U waves on ECG). Thiazide diuretics inhibit Na+ reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which increases K+ excretion and can lead to hypokalemia.

Physical examination reveals mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. Mucous membranes are slightly dry. Skin turgor and capillary refill are normal. Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate to address this patient’s hypokalemia?
